title: Hard Math Question GD
body:
Consider the set of powers of 2: 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, 64, ......
What numbers can be expressed as an alternating sum of this set?  By alternating sum it is meant that:
1 = -1 + 2
2 = -2 + 4
3= 1 - 2 + 4
4= -4 ++ 8
5= 1 - 4 + 8
and so on and so forth.

Note: 5 = -1 - 2 +8 does not work because the signs are not alternating.

Can every positive integer can be expressed this way?  If so then prove it.

Some numbers might have more than one of these expressions for example 3= 1 -2 +4 and 3= -1 + 4.  Given a number n.  How many different ways are there to write n in this fashion?  Explain.

Go nuts.
